description: From Middle English quadrat, from Old French quadrat (“a square”), from Latin quadrātus (“square”), past participle of quadrō (“to make four-cornered, square, put in order, intransitive be square”), from quadra (“a square”), later quadrus (“square”), from quattuor (“four”).

adjectives.description: quadrate (comparative more quadrate, superlative most quadrate)

entries.meaning: Having four equal sides, the opposite sides parallel, and four right angles; square.
examples: Figures, some round, some triangle, some quadrate.

entries.meaning: Produced by multiplying a number by itself; square.
examples: The number of Ten hath been as highly extolled, as containing even, odd, long, plain, quadrate and cubical numbers.
a generical description quadrate to both

entries.meaning: (geometry) A plane surface with four equal sides and four right angles; a square; hence, figuratively, anything having the outline of a square.
(astrology) An aspect of the heavenly bodies in which they are distant from each other 90°, or the quarter of a circle; quartile.

verbs.description: quadrate (third-person singular simple present quadrates, present participle quadrating, simple past and past participle quadrated)

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive) To adjust (a gun) on its carriage.
(archaic, transitive) To train (a gun) for horizontal firing.
(archaic, transitive) To square; to agree; to suit; to correspond (with).
examples: not quadrating with American ideas of right, justice and reason
